data.title: Internal Logic Pro X file format docs?
data.text:
I also want to piont out to you Des... that if anyone, (pause), does as you seemed to imply you have done in the past...you created some software solution which could read LPX data files and be generally helpful in some way. According to you and the way you are interpreting the EULA, what you did was illegal. It doesn't matter if you published the file format or not..what you did was reverse engineer the datafile format and created software based on that reverse engineering. By your definition (not mine) that is illegal. The creation of the software is that part that would be illegal according to the EULA, not the analyzing of the data file.

if you never distribute it to anyone, then guess you're ok.

I don't particularly think that is illegal either though...unless you actually clone the functionality of LogicPro itself in some way by reverse engineering any of its source code.

Ok.

Well, there's a bit of debate about the legal enforceability of EULAs - a licence agreement isn't necessary legally enforceable, as has been proved a few times in court. (Again - not a lawyer).

While I may have tinkered with files on my own computer, and developed some minor tools, this is something I have done off my own back, privately. I certainly haven't taken any knowledge of those file formats (and this is really limited stuff, like finding the positions of a tempo event in a file and changing it), and documented or shared this online, nor have I engaged in a collaborative effort to reverse engineer the file formats in detail, or publish any findings on that - and nor do I want to.

Even in this thread, or others, where this issue has come up, I haven't shared any actual information (what little there is) for the reasons I outline above.

It's my personal opinion that I'm more of less free to examine or change any of my own files I save on my computer. I'm fairly sure that (again - not a lawyer), Apple's legal team couldn't care less that I found and mapped out a handful of parameters *in my own data files* saved from Logic. It's not like I'm attempting to recover Logic's source code or tamper with Apple's software files. At worst, this could be interpreted as breaking the EULA, for which the result could be, what - revoking of my licence? There is no damage being done, so it's difficult for Apple to claim my actions caused them harm. And from what you say above, you largely agree with me on this.

Let's face it, people tinker with these files all the time - there are commercial software tools to change, edit and replace Logic's graphics files contained within the application to skin it, along with other things. None of these applications have been shut down, so I really think that editing my own data files does not constitute a problem - and even if so, far less of a problem that people selling software commercially to edit Apple-created Logic configuration files that are actually part of Apple's distributed software.

However, had I extensively reversed the file format, and *published it online* for others to use, then this is more of a problem because it can possibly be interpreted as distributing confidential Apple information - this is *potentially* a much more severe situation - which again, I've been fairly clear to discourage in this thread. It's possible that you may be right, and Apple wouldn't care, but it's also possible that they would. I certainly wouldn't be brave enough to find out, nor am I motivated in any way to do this.

Anyway, this is getting tiresome. My point was that earlier in the thread, you were saying (feel free to correct me if I'm wrong, I'm not going to go back and quote you verbatim) that you could see no reason that Apple could stop, or even care, about people disseminating information regarding the Logic file format online. That was the thing I disagreed with, and I continue to feel that way. *Discussing* it is OK in my opinion, but publishing details is over the line, for me at least.

You are entitled to feel otherwise. Other than that, I really feel like I've said all I want to say on this topic now (actually, I felt that a while back, but here we are...)

There is some brief investigation into the actual content of various chunks, and it doesn't look too bad in terms of difficulty. Meaning that when you change one thing in the Logic project and save, it results in only one (or a few) changes in the project file. It doesn't seem like the data is obfuscated/packed in any way.

Great, thanks for this, I’ll take a look a bit later on. In my experience, the data is a bit variable - there was plenty of stuff up in the header chunks that were easy to read (things like project tempo and time formats etc) and the MIDI data was more or less similar to midifile formats etc - mostly the stuff that comes from early versions of Logic is generally straightforward. However, other chunks do indeed look like chunks of binary data, where changing one single property did severely change the data in the file. I’m guessing In these cases, Logic is just basically dumping the internal objects serialised into the file, and we’d need to know more about the internal object representations.

In any case, maybe we can do some kind of community effort to reverse engineer enough of the file format to do something useful. The kind of tools I had in mind to build were reporting tools to batch out eg the plugins used in the project, a list of assets and so on, and another one that could potentially identify and fix various project corruption issues, to give us a possible way to recover as much of a corrupted project as possible, where it otherwise wouldn’t load into Logic
